Article.ArticleTitle: Short-Term Association between Sulfur Dioxide and Mortality: A Multicountry Analysis in 399 Cities.

AbstractText: Epidemiological evidence on the health risks of sulfur dioxide (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>SO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) is more limited compared with other pollutants, and doubts remain on several aspects, such as the form of the exposure-response relationship, the potential role of copollutants, as well as the actual risk at low concentrations and possible temporal variation in risks.

Our aim was to assess the short-term association between exposure to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>SO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and daily mortality in a large multilocation data set, using advanced study designs and statistical techniques.

The analysis included 43,729,018 deaths that occurred in 399 cities within 23 countries between 1980 and 2018. A two-stage design was applied to assess the association between the daily concentration of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>SO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and mortality counts, including first-stage time-series regressions and second-stage multilevel random-effect meta-analyses. Secondary analyses assessed the exposure-response shape and the lag structure using spline terms and distributed lag models, respectively, and temporal variations in risk using a longitudinal meta-regression. Bi-pollutant models were applied to examine confounding effects of particulate matter with an aerodynamic diameter of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mi>m</mi></mrow></math> (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mspace></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mi>m</mi></mrow></math> (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>), ozone, nitrogen dioxide, and carbon monoxide. Associations were reported as relative risks (RRs) and fractions of excess deaths.

The average daily concentration of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>SO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> across the 399 cities was <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>11</mn><msup><mrow><mo>.</mo><mn>7</mn><mi> μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, with 4.7% of days above the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline limit (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>40</mn><msup><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, 24-h average), although the exceedances occurred predominantly in specific locations. Exposure levels decreased considerably during the study period, from an average concentration of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>19.0</mn><mspace></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math> in 1980-1989 to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>6.3</mn><msup><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math> in 2010-2018. For all locations combined, a <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext>-</mtext><msup><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math> increase in daily <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>SO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> was associated with an RR of mortality of 1.0045 [95% confidence interval (CI): 1.0019, 1.0070], with the risk being stable over time but with substantial between-country heterogeneity. Short-term exposure to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>SO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> was associated with an excess mortality fraction of 0.50% [95% empirical CI (eCI): 0.42%, 0.57%] in the 399 cities, although decreasing from 0.74% (0.61%, 0.85%) in 1980-1989 to 0.37% (0.27%, 0.47%) in 2010-2018. There was some evidence of nonlinearity, with a steep exposure-response relationship at low concentrations and the risk attenuating at higher levels. The relevant lag window was 0-3 d. Significant positive associations remained after controlling for other pollutants.

The analysis revealed independent mortality risks associated with short-term exposure to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>SO</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, with no evidence of a threshold. Levels below the current WHO guidelines for 24-h averages were still associated with substantial excess mortality, indicating the potential benefits of stricter air quality standards. https://doi.org/10.1289/EHP11112.
